Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: FODAVA: Spectral Analysis for Fraud Detection in Large-scale Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

This project takes a unified spectral transformation approach to address challenges of analyzing network topology and identifying fraud patterns in large-scale dynamic networks by using data spectral transformation with network topology visualization. Large-scale social and communication networks contain rich topological information embedded inside, in addition to various structured, semi-structured, and unstructured data. There has been little to date work dedicated to exploring network topology, especially from the spectral analysis point of view. If the proposed methods, which are based on the simple adjacency matrix representation of a graph and the node representation based on k communities in the graph, can be demonstrated to work for very large data sets, it will be a significant advance. The research is being integrated with information visualization and visual analytics algorithms and has a testbed of banking data available to allow for a search for fraud.

The research is characterizing patterns of various attacks in the spectral projection space and developing spectrum based methods to identify these attacks. The approach, which exploits the spectral space of the underlying interaction structure of the network, is orthogonal to traditional approaches using content profiling. The ability to perform this spectral analysis is dependent upon the development of complex mathematical techniques. Critical issues that are being explored include the scalability of the methods to very large data sets and the determination of the dimensionality of the node representation in spectral space (which depends upon the number of clusters in the graph). Another issue is that each component of the k-dimensional representation of each node is interpreted as the 'likelihood' of a node's attachment to the k communities. However, it must be guaranteed that the components of the k-dimensional vector that represent each node will be all nonnegative or else an interpretation of the negative number as 'likelihood' must be developed that is mathematically consistent. These and other related mathematical issues are being explored.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this project is to develop a unified spectral transformation approach to address challenges of analyzing network topology and identifying fraud patterns in large-scale dynamic networks. There are rich topological information embedded inside in current large-scale social and communication networks in addition to various structured, semi-structured, and unstructured data.

We developed effective and practical techniques for analyzing network topology by examining spectral spaces of the topological structure of the underlying network. We developed spectrum based algorithms to identify frauds and attacks including collaborative random link attacks and subtle anomalies, which are hard to be identified from the original network topology.  Our theoretical results and empirical evaluations showed that attacking nodes located in a different region of the spectral space from regular nodes. We developed a framework that analyzed graph randomness at all granularity levels, from edge, node, subgraph, to the whole graph based on the spectra of the adjacency matrix. We have extended our spectral analysis to signed graphs with both positive and negative edges and found that communities in a k-balanced signed graph are distinguishable in the spectral space even if connections between communities are very dense. 

We developed new interactive visual analytics techniques that tightly couple data spectral transformation with network topology visualization. We explored how to utilize the features of node distribution and coordinates in the high dimensional spectral space to generate a 2D visualization, which allowed users to study and interact with the data directly. We also designed network visualization and interactive analysis methods to assist the interactive exploration of network topologies. Our visualization work for signed networks addressed two essential problems of network analysis - where and what to look for in the spectral space. The interactive coordinated multi-views mechanism assisted users to analyze data features from different network and spectrum spaces. Both theoretical analysis and empirical evaluations showed the developed approach based on spectral transformation and network topology visualization is effective in detecting various frauds and anomalies from networks.

We developed one portable course module on spectrum based fraud detection and incorporated it into the graduate courses of Web mining and Illustrative Visualization. Five Ph.D. students including three female students participated in this project and have been exposed to the latest development in the area, and as a result significantly improved their research skills. Two of them successfully defended their dissertations and graduated from UNC Charlotte.  We outreached to the broader community (high school students, college undergraduate students, industry visitors, and researchers) via showcasing research results at Explore-UNCC events and local visualization and security symposiums.

The project advances theoretical understanding of fundamental issues related to spectral analysis of graph topology and its use for fraud detection. The research outcomes have impact on research areas such as graph topology analysis, matrix perturbation, data mining, and visual analytics. The project helps end users 1) design and implement practical spectrum based fraud detection techniques; and 2) meet growing expectations in deriving information from their large and dynamic data and defending against various cyber attacks and securing their applications.  Social network analysts may also use our techniques for various tasks including community partition, outlier detection, behavior analysis, and network evolution analysis.
